metadata.title: A nickel(II) complex of 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid ion, an efficient electro-catalyst for both hydrogen evolution and oxidation

A nickel(II) complex of 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid ion, an efficient electro-catalyst for both hydrogen evolution and oxidation Juan Du Project administration Writing – review & editing Hao Yang Investigation Writing – original draft Chun-Li Wang Formal analysis Shu-Zhong Zhan Methodology ⁎ College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou 510640, China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering South China University of Technology Guangzhou 510640 China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou 510640, China ⁎ Corresponding author A new electrocatalyst based on a nickel complex, [Ni(HL)2], is designed and provided by the reaction of NiCl2 with 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (H2L) in our group. Electrochemical investigations show that [Ni(HL)2] can electro-catalyze hydrogen evolution from acetic acid with a rate constant of 3454 M−2 s−1. [Ni(HL)2] also can electro-catalyze hydrogen oxidation with a rate constant of 2.047 × 104 M−2 s−1. The carboxyl group of [Ni(HL)2] may play critical roles in the catalytic hydrogen evolution and oxidation reactions. Moreover, the introduction of an electron-withdrawing group, -Cl at the pyridine of H2L leads to a decrease in the catalytic activity for hydrogen generation, and [Ni(HL)2] shows a more efficient activity than [Ni(HL-Cl)2] (H2L-Cl: 4-chloro-2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid). These findings can afford a new ideal for the design of electrocatalysts for both H2 evolution and H2 oxidation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nickel(II) complexes Electrocatalyst for hydrogen evolution and oxidation Hydrogen evolution Hydrogen oxidation 1 Introduction To meet the growing global energy demand, the development of new technologies and energy-storage schemes is required [1,2]. Based on the potential to reduce the current dependence on fossil fuels, hydrogen is an ideal energy and an alternative to fossil fuels in the future [3]. To achieve the processes of hydrogen production via hydrogen evolution reactions (HERs) and hydrogen utilization via hydrogen oxidation reactions (HORs), electrocatalysts are needed to finish the conversion between chemical energy (the H-H bond of hydrogen) and electricity [4]. It is apparent that hydrogenases with nickel or iron complexes can catalyze the reversible interconversion of molecular hydrogen with protons and electrons: H2 ⇌ 2H+ + 2e− [5,6]. But the stability is often limited outside of their native environment [5,6]. To try to mimic the behavior of this natural process, several complexes of transition metals have been designed and developed as catalysts for H2 generation [7–14]. Another direction, several groups, including our own, have focused the interests on the developments of abundant metal-based catalysts for hydrogen oxidation [15–21]. However, there have been few catalysts based on complexes reported in the literature that can function efficiently as both hydrogen oxidation catalysts (HOCs) and hydrogen evolution catalysts (HECs) [4,21,22]. To this goal, we focus our interests on the design of new complexes that catalyze the reaction in both directions (hydrogen evolution and oxidation). Reported here is the synthesis and characterization of a nickel(II) complex, [Ni(HL)2], as well as its electro-catalytic properties for hydrogen evolution and oxidation. 2 Experimental Physical measurements, X-ray crystallography for the nickel complex, [Ni(HL)2] and the description for equations were listed in “Supplementary materials” Synthesis of the nickel complex, [Ni(HL)2] 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (H2L) (0.167 g, 1 mmol) and NiCl2 .6H2O (0.120 g, 0.50 mmol) were dissolved in 10 mL methanol respectively, then were mixed and stirred for 15 min. Violet crystals were obtained from the filtrate which was allowed to stand at room temperature for several days, collected by filtration, and dried in vacuo (60% yield). Calcd for C14H8NiO8N2: C, 34.97; H, 2.58; N, 7.16. Found: C, 34.78; H, 2.57; N, 7.21. 3 Results and discussion 3 1 General characterization for [Ni(HL)2] The ligand, 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (H2L) reacts with NiCl2 to afford a new nickel(II) complex, [Ni(HL)2] (Scheme 1 ), which is agreement with the following single crystal X-ray structural analysis and ESI-MS analysis. As shown in Fig. 1-(a), the nickel center is six-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms and four oxygen atoms from the ligand, HL−. The lengths of two Ni–N bands are 1.962(4) and 1.970(4) Å, respectively, whilst the Ni–O distances are range from 2.096(4) to 2.186(4) Å. Based on that the longer Ni-O bonds have greater ionic character, it can account for better water solubility and more facile hydration, both important features for an effective homogeneous proton reduction catalyst or hydrogen oxidation catalysts. This result also agrees with the following measurements and analysis. 1) [Ni(HL)2] is soluble in water and common organic solvents, such as DMF and CH3CN, etc. 2) [Ni(HL)2] exhibited one ion at a mass-to-charge ratio (m/z) of 392.0359 (Fig. S1), with mass and isotope distribution pattern corresponding to [Ni(HL)2-H]+. 3.2 Electro-catalytic hydrogen evolution by [Ni(HL)2] Inspired by that nickel complexes can serve as electrocatalysts for hydrogen evolution [13,19,21,23], we investigated the electrocatalytic behaviors of the nickel complex, [Ni(HL)2]. First, the cyclic voltammograms of [Ni(HL)2] and the related sample were measured. As shown in Fig. S2, the ligand, H2L exhibited a quasi-reversible couple at -1.45 V versus Ag/AgNO3. Compared with the ligand, [Ni(HL)2] displayed two quasi-reversible couples at -1.95 and 1.04 V versus Ag/AgNO3, which can be attributed to the NiII/I and NiIII/II couples, respectively (Fig. 1-(b)). Moreover, the current responses of the redox events at 0.98, -1.46 and -2.10 V versus Ag/AgNO3 show linear dependence on the square root of the scan rate (Fig. S3), which is an indicative of a diffusion-controlled process, with the electrochemically active species freely diffusing in the solution. Next, acetic acid was introduced as a proton resource to check electrocatalytic activity. As shown in Fig. 1-(b), with addition of varied contents of acetic acid from 0.0 to 20.0 mM, a systematic increase in the voltammetric currents emerging at -2.10 V versus Ag/AgNO3 was discovered, which is attributed to a catalytic process for hydrogen evolution [24,25], indicating that the reduction of Ni(II) to Ni(I) and protonation are responsible for hydrogen generation. To understand kinetic behaviors for hydrogen evolution of [Ni(HL)2], a series of voltametric measurements and analyses were carried out. As displayed in Fig. S4, the plot of the catalytic current (ip) versus the concentration of [Ni(HL)2] gave a linear correlation, indicating the reaction is first-order with respect to the catalyst concentration. Next, cyclic voltammograms of [Ni(HL)2] (1.58 mM) were recorded with a series of acetic acid concentrations under varying scan rates, giving the results shown Figs. S5-S10. Based on the data listed in Fig. S4 and Figs. S5-S10, the relationships of the ratios of ic/ip versus the acetic acid concentration or scan rates were investigated. According to Fig. 2-(a), the plots of the ratio (ic/ip) versus the acetic acid concentration at varying scan rates gave a linear correlation, respectively, indicating the reaction is second order with respect to the acetic acid concentration. To further investigate the catalytic efficiency for hydrogen evolution, several models were employed. Combining Equation (1) with Equation (2) to afford the relationship of the electrocatalytic current (icat) with the current for a reversible redox process for the electrocatalyst (ip) (Equation (3)) [26]. Then, k, which is usually referred as turnover frequency (TOF) of the catalyst can be expressed in Equation (3). (1) i c = n F A [ c a t ] D k [ H + ] 2 (2) i p = 0.4463 F A [ c a t ] R T k [ H + ] 2 F v (3) i c i p = n 0.4463 R T k [ H + ] 2 F v ip= The peak current observed for the NiII/I couple under one atmosphere N2 in the absence of acetic acid. ic= the peak or plateau current observed in the presence of various amounts of acetic acid. n is the number of electrons involved in the catalytic reaction (2 for H2 evolution). Based on the relationship between the ratios of ic/ip and the acid concentration (Fig. 2-(b)), the acid concentration for a process that is second order in acid (n= 2), the scan rate ν, and Equation (3), the catalytic efficiency for hydrogen evolution by [Ni(HL)2] was calculated to be 3454 M−2 s−1. The electrocatalytic efficiency for hydrogen evolution in organic media is lower than the reported nickel-based catalysts [26], because of the Ni(II)/Ni(I) redox process of [Ni(HL)2] at -2.45 V versus Cp2Fe+/0 (Fig. 1-(b)). This value is much more negative than those of the reported nickel complexes (-1.04 − -1.14 V versus Cp2Fe+/0) [26], which suggests that electron-transfer between the electrode and [Ni(HL)2] is less feasible, leading to lower rate for hydrogen production [27,28]. Taking into account that [Ni(HL)2] is soluble in water (a proton resource), we also explored electrochemical properties of this nickel complex in aqueous media, a much more attractive medium for the sustainable hydrogen generation. From Fig. S11, as decreasing pH values from 7.0 to 4.0, the strength of the reduction wave of [Ni(HL)2] increased, and the onset of the catalytic wave were shifted to higher potentials from -1.81 to -1.28 V versus Ag/AgCl, which are consistent with a catalytic process for water reduction [29]. Furthermore, with an increase on the concentration of [Ni(HL)2], a systematic increase in icat was found (Fig. S12). To get further insight into the evidence for the catalytic activity of [Ni(HL)2], bulk electrolysis in an aqueous buffer without or with [Ni(HL)2] (5.85 μM) was conducted. Fig. 3 mapped out the electrochemical behaviors of [Ni(HL)2] under varying applied potentials. As the applied potentials were set to more negative, the charge significantly increased. For instance, in the presence of 5.85 μM [Ni(HL)2], the electrolysis of a neutral aqueous solution (pH 7.0) could afford a charge of 1097 mC during 2 min of electrolysis under -1.45 V versus Ag/AgCl (Fig. 3-(a)), accompanying generation of H2, which was confirmed by gas chromatography. According to the data listed in Fig. S13-(a), a 0.5 h electrolysis of a neutral aqueous solution (pH 7.0) with 5.85 μM [Ni(HL)2] could provide 3.2 mL of H2 (Equation S1) [30] and the Faradaic efficiency was about 92% (Fig. S11-(b)). Yet, under the identical condition, the electrolysis of a neutral aqueous solution without [Ni(HL)2] only gave 52 mC of charge (Fig. 3-(b)). These findings reveal that [Ni(HL)2] does serve as an effective electrocatalyst for hydrogen generation from water under such conditions. Moreover, Equations (4) [31] and (5) [32] were employed to calculate catalytic efficiencies and overpotentials, respectively, giving the results listed in Fig. S14. For example, [Ni(HL)2] could electrocatalyze hydrogen evolution with a TOF of 679.56 mol H2/mol catalyst/h under an OP of 837.6 mV (Equation S2). (4) T O F = Δ C / ( F * n 1 * n 2 * t ) (5) O v e r p o t e n t i a l = A p p l i e d p o t e n t i a l − E ( p H ) = A p p l i e d p o t e n t i a l − ( − 0.059 p H ) To investigate the substituent effect on the hydrogen evolution reaction, [Ni(HL)2] was replaced by [Ni(HL-Cl)2] (Scheme 2 ) as an electrocatalyst, with the results shown in Fig. S15. Together the data listed in Fig. S15 with Equations 4-5, the electrocatalytic system with [Ni(HL-Cl)2] could provide 523.5 moles of hydrogen per mole of catalyst per hour under an OP of 836.6 mV (Fig. S16). Therefore, [Ni(HL)2] shows a more efficient activity for hydrogen evolution than [Ni(HL-Cl)2]. This result is consistent with a decrease in the catalytic activity when a weakly activating electron donating group, -Cl is present at the pyridine of the ligand, H2L and 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid ions constitute a better active catalyst than 4-chloro-2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid ions [33–36]. To show that [Ni(HL)2] is an efficient electrocatalyst in aqueous media, some reported catalysts were listed in Table 1 . Under similar conditions, the electro-catalytic activity of [Ni(HL)2] (679.56 mol H2/mol catalyst/h at an OP of 837.6 mV) is also higher than some known complexes for electrocatalytic H2 evolution from a neutral aqueous buffer. For instance, a cobalt complex, CoL1 can provide 184.3 mol H2/mol catalyst/h at an OP of 837.6 mV [37], a nickel complex, [Ni(mnt)2]− can afford 504.25 mol H2/mol catalyst/h at an OP of 837.6 mV [38], and a nickel complex, NiL2 electrocatalyzes hydrogen evolution with a TOF of 574 mol H2/mol catalyst/h at an OP of 837.6 mV [39] (Table 1). In addition, the catalytic activities of other reported nickel-based catalysts [40] were also showed in Table 1. 3.3 Stability of the electrocatalytic system with [Ni(HL)2] for hydrogen evolution To examine the stability of [Ni(HL)2], we conducted a series of experiments. As shown in Fig. S17-(a), when measurements for cyclic voltammograms of [Ni(HL)2] were repeated 20 times, the current strengths remained almost constant. Moreover, after an electrochemical measurement of [Ni(HL)2], a subsequent CV measurement did not show any catalytic behavior distinct from that of the pristine electrode (Fig. S17-(b)), indicating that no deposit is formed on electrode, and [Ni(HL)2] is stable during electrochemical measurements (Equation (6)) [41]. And several pieces of evidence also confirm that [Ni(HL)2] is a stable catalyst: 1) The electrochemical reduction of [Ni(HL)2] at -1.45 V versus Ag/AgCl resulted in no new absorption appeared (Fig. S18). 2) With [Ni(HL)2] as an electrocatalyst, the strength of catalytic current was sustained for at least 8 h (Fig. S19). 3) There was no evidence for precipitation formation on the working electrode by energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) and scanning electron microscope (SEM) (Fig. S20) after 8 h electrolysis. (6) [ N i I I − ( H L ) 2 ] 2 + + 2 e − N i + 2 H L − 2 3.4 Electrocatalytic hydrogen oxidation by [Ni(HL)2] Encouraged by that nickel complexes also can act as electrocatalysts for hydrogen oxidation [16,18,19,21], we also tried to explore the catalytic performance for hydrogen oxidation of [Ni(HL)2], a much more attractive medium for the sustainable generation and storage of hydrogen energy. As shown in Fig. S21, under 1.0 atm of H2, CV of a DMF solution of 0.025 M triethylamine (TEA) showed no obvious redox signs. The cyclic voltammograms of [Ni(HL)2] recorded on solutions bubbled with hydrogen were showed in Fig. 4. The introduction of hydrogen resulted in an increase on the current strength of the oxidation peak at 0.91 V versus Ag/AgNO3, which can be assigned to the hydrogen addition adduct (Fig. 4-(a)) [26]. Moreover, with addition of varied contents of triethylamine from 1.60 to 20.80 mM, a systematic increase in the voltammetric currents emerging at 0.96 V versus Ag/AgNO3 was found (Fig. 4-(b)). These findings are agreement with a catalytic process for hydrogen oxidation and the formation of hydrogen addition product, such as HNEt3 + (Equation (7)) [15,42,43], indicating that the oxidation of Ni(II) to Ni(III) is responsible for hydrogen oxidation. To further characterize hydrogen oxidation product, a Verkade's base (2,8,9-triisopropyl-2,5,8,9-tetraaza-1-phosphabicyclo[3.3.3]undecane) 1 was introduced as a proton acceptor. As shown in Fig. S22, in the presence of Verkade's base 1, the electrolysis of 0.10 M of [n-Bu4N]ClO4 DMF solution with [Ni(HL)2] (1.0 mM) under H2 atmosphere resulted in a new peak appeared at 10.8 ppm, which can be attributed to 1H+. (7) H2+2NEt3 ⇌2HNEt3 ++2e- Combining these observations, analyses, and the reported points [18,19,21,42,43], a possible catalytic cycle for hydrogen oxidation was schemed. As shown in Scheme 3 , the carboxyl group of [Ni(HL)2] may play critical roles in the catalytic hydrogen oxidation reaction, facilitating heterolytic cleavage of the H-H bond and mediating proton transfer between the nickel center and exogenous base (TEA). The roles of the carboxyl group for the hydride, [H-Ni(HL)2] can be analogous to those thought to be employed by the active of the [Fe-Ni] hydrogenase [5]. To further characterize catalytic activities for hydrogen oxidation of [Ni(HL)2], a series of voltametric measurements were carried out with varying amount of triethylamine or scan rates. As shown in Fig. S23, the plot of the catalytic current (icat) versus the concentration of [Ni(HL)2] provided a linear correlation, indicating the reaction is first-order with respect to the catalyst concentration. Based on Equation (8) and the data listed in Fig. S24, the linear relationship between icat/ip versus the base concentration suggests the catalytic rate is second order (x= 2) in TEA concentration, providing Equation (9) [44,45]. (8) i c i p = n 0.4463 RTk [ Base ] x Fv (9) i c i p = n 0.4463 RTk [ Base ] 2 Fv ip= The peak current for the NiIII/II couple under 1.0 atm H2 in the absence of TEA. ic= the peak or plateau current observed in the presence of various amounts of TEA. n is the number of electrons involved in the catalytic reaction (2 for H2 oxidation). Additionally, cyclic voltammograms of [Ni(HL)2] (1.20 mM) were carried out with a series of concentrations of TEA under varied scan rates, with the results shown Figs. S25-S32. According to the data shown in Fig. S23 and Figs. S25-S32, the relationships between the ratios of ic/ip versus the base concentrations or scan rates were studied. From Fig. 5 -(a), the plots of the ratio (ic/ip) versus the concentrations of TEA at varying scan rates afforded a linear correlation, respectively, indicating the reaction is third order with respect to the TEA concentration. Together the relationship between the ratios of ic/ip versus the base concentration (Fig. 5-(b)), the base concentration for a process that is second order in TEA (n= 2), the scan rate ν, with Equation (9), the catalytic efficiency for hydrogen oxidation was estimated to be 2.047 × 104 M−2 s−1. 4 Conclusions In this paper, we describe a new nickel complex, [Ni(HL)2] that is afforded by the reaction of 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (H2L) with NiCl2. [Ni(HL)2] has been fully characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, ESI-MS, and electrochemical methods, etc. Electrochemical investigations reveal that [Ni(HL)2] shows efficient activities for both hydrogen generation and oxidation. Moreover, another nickel complex, [Ni(HL-Cl)2] is employed as an electrocatalyst to investigate the substituent effect on the hydrogen evolution reaction. The results show that 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid ions constitute a better active catalyst than 4-chloro-2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid ions. Our ongoing efforts are focused on modifying ligands to afford the related complexes that can serve as catalysts both for hydrogen evolution reaction (HERs) and hydrogen oxidation reactions (HORs). coredata.dc:description: A new electrocatalyst based on a nickel complex, [Ni(HL)2], is designed and provided by the reaction of NiCl2 with 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (H2L) in our group. Electrochemical investigations show that [Ni(HL)2] can electro-catalyze hydrogen evolution from acetic acid with a rate constant of 3454 M−2 s−1. [Ni(HL)2] also can electro-catalyze hydrogen oxidation with a rate constant of 2.047 × 104 M−2 s−1. The carboxyl group of [Ni(HL)2] may play critical roles in the catalytic hydrogen evolution and oxidation reactions. Moreover, the introduction of an electron-withdrawing group, -Cl at the pyridine of H2L leads to a decrease in the catalytic activity for hydrogen generation, and [Ni(HL)2] shows a more efficient activity than [Ni(HL-Cl)2] (H2L-Cl: 4-chloro-2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid). These findings can afford a new ideal for the design of electrocatalysts for both H2 evolution and H2 oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: A nickel(II) complex of 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid ion, an efficient electro-catalyst for both hydrogen evolution and oxidation

dcterms:subject.$: Electrocatalyst for hydrogen evolution and oxidation
